posts.author: CriticalElf
posts.content:
I've been thinking about multiclass lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about multiclass that came up in our game last night.

What are the best multiclass combinations that synergize well with multiclass? I'm particularly interested in optimizing for combat effectiveness.

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about multiclass?

posts.author: WizardlyWisdom
posts.content:
I think the 2024 changes to Cleric/Paladin make it much more balanced compared to before.

When DMing, I like to use Cleric/Paladin as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

For my next character, I want to focus on Cleric/Paladin as a central feature. What subclasses or multiclass options would work best with this?

posts.author: FighterFanatic
posts.content:
For my next character, I want to focus on viable? as a central feature. What subclasses or multiclass options would work best with this?

In our last session, we encountered a Lich and tried to use viable? to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use viable? to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

posts.author: DruidicDreamer
posts.content:
My DM interprets multiclass differently than the rules as written. How do you all handle this at your tables?

In our last session, we encountered a Beholder and tried to use multiclass to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

The way I understand the rules for multiclass, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

posts.author: WarlocksWisdom
posts.content:
In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how Cleric/Paladin works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

How do other DMs balance encounters that involve Cleric/Paladin? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use Cleric/Paladin to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about Cleric/Paladin. Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: CriticalMiss
posts.content:
I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for Cleric/Paladin are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

My DM interprets Cleric/Paladin differently than the rules as written. How do you all handle this at your tables?

The way I understand the rules for Cleric/Paladin, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

In my campaign, we had a situation with Cleric/Paladin that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.
